reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on the idea that Eve was Merlin and didn’t sufficiently challenge that assumption after Mission 2 and especially after the double-fail on Mission 3. I did reasonably well at not making myself look like Merlin, but I needed to be more active in steering teams away from Eve and Diana once there were clear data points against them.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cleanly and consistently, which made him look reliably good; he didn’t over-defend anyone, which limited useful alignment signals.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as cautious and analytical, but his inclusions on early teams (that later failed) unintentionally gave cover to evil by making the blame more diffuse.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced aggression and subtlety well; she slid onto early teams without drawing attention and used the Mission 2 fail to sow just enough doubt without overexposing herself.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the ‘I might be Merlin’ narrative effectively by leaning into confident reads and volunteering for key missions, which successfully drew my Percival read toward her.
player_observations.Frank: Played a low-key Merlin, giving nudges rather than hard pushes; while this kept him relatively safe, it also made it easier for evil to outshine him as the perceived information role.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed in the background but capitalized on opportunities to push or support teams that ended up failing, doing so in a way that didn’t look overtly coordinated.
player_observations.Henry: Behaved like a straightforward good player—logical and not overly dramatic—but didn’t assert strongly enough to counter the misleading narratives pushed by evil-leaning players.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and built early trust by being on two teams that only had a single fail each, which helped keep suspicion off me and preserved my influence in table talk. I could have pushed harder on the implications of Mission 2 and 3 fails—especially pressing why Diana and Eve kept ending up on critical teams—and been more vocal about protecting Frank once he started looking like a likely Merlin candidate.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very flexible evil game, mixing safe early behavior with just enough subtle steering to keep suspicion spread out; his late-game positioning for the assassination was strong.
player_observations.Charlie: Generally reasoned from mission data in a straightforward, logical way and seemed genuinely transparent, which made him read as pretty clearly good for much of the game.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to stay relatively under the radar despite being on the failing Mission 2 and 4 teams; blended in well with good’s reasoning and avoided big, attention-grabbing accusations.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the fake-Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well, projecting confidence and giving very pointed reads that likely misled Grace and made it harder for good to converge on the true Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: Took the right kinds of risks with his team selections as Merlin while not over-defending the wrong people, but ended up just visible enough in his accuracy that evil could line him up for the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: Was active and engaged in deduction, but seemed heavily influenced by Eve’s confident table talk; her Merlin/percival information read didn’t quite land, which hurt good’s late-game focus.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a cautious good player, generally trusting mission data and not forcing wild theories; his conservative leadership on Mission 4 didn’t manage to avoid stacking evil, but his reasoning stayed mostly consistent with a good perspective.

reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was willing to go on early missions and provide a clean success, which helped establish at least some initial trust. I could have done better at narrowing down the source of the Mission 2 fail and being more vocal about pushing suspicion onto the right people instead of staying relatively passive as the game progressed.

player_observations.Bob: Played fairly quietly and blended into the background, which is strong for Percival but made it harder to clearly see how he was interpreting Merlin/Morgana signals.
player_observations.Charlie: Did a solid job as Merlin of not looking too obvious, but may have been slightly too cautious in steering teams, which let evil slip through on later missions.
player_observations.Diana: Generally came across as reasonable and thoughtful in team building, but the Mission 4 team composition suggests she might have trusted at least one evil player too much.
player_observations.Eve: Sold herself well as a trustworthy player early on, leveraging the clean Mission 1 result and later using confusion around roles to avoid focused suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he inserted himself into key missions and managed to cause critical fails while staying just plausible enough to avoid being hard-cleared evil after Mission 2.
player_observations.Grace: Looked genuinely good most of the game and was willing to go on risky teams, but sometimes followed group consensus a bit too readily rather than challenging suspicious setups.
player_observations.Henry: Played a patient, low-profile Assassin game and benefited from others’ misreads; he avoided drawing too much heat while still being on the decisive failing team.

reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too hard on the early success with Charlie and Henry, which made me slow to fully pivot away from Charlie after the mission 2 fail and especially after the double fail on mission 3. I also didn’t push hard enough to keep Grace off the later teams, treating her mission 4 success as stronger evidence of being good than it actually was. On the positive side, I consistently kept myself on teams and helped secure the missions we did pass, but my team selection logic needed to adapt faster to the emerging fail patterns.

player_observations.Bob: Played a fairly consensus-driven, cooperative game and seemed to prioritize building broadly acceptable teams, which unfortunately led to including Grace on mission 5 and giving evil the final fail. His style felt more reactive than proactive in terms of accusing or clearing people.
player_observations.Charlie: Used the successful first mission to lock in a strong appearance of innocence and leaned on that trust through the midgame. As Mordred, he timed his fails well and stayed consistent enough in his table talk that suspicion on him never fully solidified when it should have.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she appeared to have some good instincts but had to stay subtle, which made her nudges easy to ignore or interpret as normal table chatter. Her caution in openly pushing against specific players may have cost some influence over the final team compositions.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive and convincingly good-leaning role, especially when joining mission 3 and contributing to the double fail that created significant confusion. She balanced being active in discussion with not drawing so much attention that she became an obvious evil candidate.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed to struggle to translate his Merlin/ Morgana information into effective steering of the group, possibly being unsure which of Diana or Eve was actually Merlin. His contributions felt earnest but not quite forceful enough to shift the table at key moments.
player_observations.Grace: Maintained a relatively low-key but trustworthy image, crucially choosing success on mission 4 to appear cleared and then delivering the decisive fail on mission 5. Her willingness to blend in and avoid heavy accusation battles made her a very effective assassin here.
player_observations.Henry: Was on several early teams and, because of the surrounding fails, absorbed some ambient suspicion despite being consistently good. His style was straightforward and cooperative, but he didn’t push hard to reframe narratives when he was being indirectly implicated.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted the early Mission 1 team and helped stabilize a good core, but I overtrusted Eve after the clean Mission 3 and didn't push hard enough on the logic after Mission 4. I should have more clearly argued that Bob was almost certainly evil from the Mission 2/4 pattern and then re-examined Eve’s position before Mission 5 instead of treating that group as automatically safe.

player_observations.Bob: Comfortable taking risky team compositions and sliding onto teams where he could hide among trusted players, especially around Missions 2 and 4.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed out of early mission scrutiny and was willing to send a very mixed team on Mission 5, suggesting a preference for late-game decisive plays rather than early influence.
player_observations.Diana: Played in a very low-impact, low-suspicion way; even after being on the failed Mission 2, did not attract much sustained blame or attention.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in extremely well by passing a key early mission (Mission 3), then leveraging that trust to keep getting on critical teams later.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a steady, reasonable voice, which fit as Merlin—he nudged teams in good directions without being too obvious, but may have been slightly too willing to keep Eve on teams.
player_observations.Grace: Assertive and logical as an early leader, and then leaned heavily into trusting the Mission 3 core, which helped evil stay embedded once that group was seen as safe.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforward and earnest, but his leadership on the failed Mission 2 made him an easy scapegoat even though he was actually good.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly town-read Eve fairly early and tried to keep pressure off Henry, but I didn’t do enough to clearly signal that I saw the Merlin/Morgana split and publicly lock in Henry as more likely Merlin. I also tunneled too much on team-based logic from Missions 2 and 3 without re-evaluating when new info came from Mission 4, which let evil coordinate around my uncertainty. Next time, I should be more vocal and structured about my Merlin reads so good has a clearer narrative to follow.

player_observations.Bob: Bold and opportunistic; he leaned into high-impact leadership on Mission 4 and was willing to stack a risky team that created maximum confusion when it failed with two cards.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a quieter, more reactive good game, which made it harder to confidently clear him; he didn’t push strong theories but tended to follow emerging consensus.
player_observations.Diana: Very smooth and persuasive as Morgana, fitting naturally into good-team logic and using mission outcomes to keep suspicion spread out rather than focused on herself.
player_observations.Eve: Consistently read as good-aligned due to straightforward, transparent reasoning and relatively clean mission history, especially after Mission 1’s success.
player_observations.Frank: Played a low-visibility Mordred game, avoiding being the center of debates while still slipping onto a crucial failing team in Mission 2 and not drawing sustained heat afterward.
player_observations.Grace: Reasonable and measured, but slightly passive; she felt genuinely good, yet didn’t push hard enough to reshape the narrative when evil teams started slipping through.
player_observations.Henry: Very strong as Merlin, giving good nudges without overexposing himself, but subtle enough that I didn’t capitalize fully on his hints to hard-protect him and drive the team selections.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well staying consistently on early successful teams and projecting a generally trustworthy presence, which helped keep suspicion off me. I could improve by being more aggressive in locking out previously suspicious players (especially Grace and Frank after Missions 3 and 4) and pushing harder for team comps that preserved known-safe patterns instead of conceding to wider, more flexible teams late.

player_observations.Bob: Played a low-profile but solid good game; being on a fail-free Mission 2 and then the failed Mission 3 without overreacting kept him looking reasonably trustworthy, but he could have been more vocal about locking in earlier success-pattern teams.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, seemed genuinely conflicted about the Merlin signals, which made his pushes feel cautious rather than decisive; that caution late made it easier for evil to sneak into Mission 5.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in very well as evil by not taking early risks and only appearing on the final critical mission, which made the single fail there feel more ambiguous and hard to pin purely on her.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as a very reasonable good player, especially by being absent from the first failed mission and then present on a later failing one in a way that didn’t strongly incriminate her, but could have argued more strongly to repeat safer cores.
player_observations.Frank: Played a quiet but very effective Mordred game; slipping onto Mission 4 for a single fail without drawing overwhelming backlash set up a lot of late-game confusion about whether the problem was him or a previously trusted player.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she leveraged her early presence on successful teams to look clean, then used that trust to slip a fail onto a midgame mission without getting fully locked out afterwards.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, he walked a fine line between steering teams toward safer options and not over-telegraphing his knowledge; his subtlety kept him alive information-wise but also left just enough ambiguity for evil to assemble the final winning team.

reflections.self_assessment: Early on I correctly suspected that Eve was evil after Mission 3, but I didn’t push hard enough to translate that into consistent trust in Diana as Merlin. I need to be more forceful about excluding Grace from critical teams once the pool of likely evils is narrowed, and communicate my Merlin read more clearly without over-explaining.

player_observations.Bob: Played in a very steady, low-flash way that made you blend into the background, which is good for a generic good role but sometimes made you harder to firmly clear or rally around.
player_observations.Charlie: You felt naturally trusted early, repeatedly going on teams and keeping them clean when you were on, which helped good but you didn’t strongly drive the table when suspicions shifted.
player_observations.Diana: Your Merlin signals were subtle and cautious, which protected you from assassination but also made it harder for me, as Percival, to fully lock onto you over Eve until later than ideal.
player_observations.Eve: You sold the Merlin persona effectively, especially early, by being confidently involved in team-building and acting like you had extra info, which pulled my attention toward you in the Percival read.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed out of the spotlight after your failed Mission 2 team, letting suspicion land more on others; that reserved style worked well for Mordred by not tying you directly to the failure in discussion.
player_observations.Grace: You played a very flexible, adaptive game—comfortable going on both successful and failing teams—which made you look ‘pragmatic good’ and let you sneak onto the final critical mission.
player_observations.Henry: You appeared genuinely uncertain and open in discussion, which read as a very natural good tone and made it easy to want you on later teams, even though we didn’t fully leverage that trust to coordinate a cleaner final lineup.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Charlie and Bob too easily after the double-success start and didn’t re-evaluate strongly enough after the first fail, which let evil anchor themselves in every critical team. I also didn’t push hard enough for Henry or Frank as core picks late game, so I contributed to stacked evil presence on Missions 4 and 5. Next time I should be more aggressive about questioning previously trusted players after any new fail, even if the earlier missions were clean.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very convincing Percival, projecting a lot of confidence that made his support feel safe, but that also meant his continued backing of Charlie subtly anchored suspicion away from the real evil core.
player_observations.Charlie: Maintained a steady, calm presence and used the early clean missions to build long-term trust, then leveraged that to get onto and even lead critical late-game teams while being evil Morgana.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed relatively under the radar and let others (especially Charlie) handle table direction, which helped her avoid suspicion despite being on the successful early mission and later a failing one.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly good and was willing to be on teams without over-arguing, but didn’t push strong alternative theories, which made it easier for evil to sideline her reads.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solid and reasonably trustworthy but didn’t gain enough table influence to steer team composition, so his good alignment didn’t translate into strong control over the later missions.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed mostly in the background as Mordred, avoiding sharp takes that would draw heat while still sliding onto the final mission, which helped keep the true evil configuration obscured until it was too late.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, tried to subtly nudge teams away from certain players without being too obvious, but the table didn’t fully follow his signals, and my misreads meant his soft pushes didn’t get enough support.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed consistently on early successful teams, which helped me look trustworthy, but I didn’t convert that trust into stronger pushes against the wrong teams later. I should have pressed harder on the pattern of Bob/Frank/Charlie/Henry being over-represented on critical missions and been more skeptical when Mission 3 failed. As leader on Mission 4, I could have tightened my team selection more aggressively around the most consistently clean players instead of spreading risk.

player_observations.Bob: Bob appeared consistently trustworthy by being on the first two successful missions, which made it easy to clear him mentally and likely made evil comfortable hiding next to him. He didn’t strongly challenge later team compositions, which indirectly let evil shape Missions 3 and 5 without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie slipped smoothly onto the successful Mission 2 and then onto the failing Mission 3, using that early success to mask his role as Mordred. He played a low-profile, quietly-included style that avoided drawing attention even after the first fail, which was effective at keeping suspicion spread out.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival and the final mission leader, Diana tried to balance information with team selection but ended up including two evil players on Mission 5. Her team choices suggested she was partially misreading Merlin’s signals or over-trusting certain players who had been on mixed-result missions. She played actively and took on responsibility, but her late-game read was just off enough to swing the result.
player_observations.Eve: Eve maintained enough ambiguity to get onto the crucial Mission 4 and then the final Mission 5, contributing to both fails as the Assassin. She didn’t need to be heavily vocal; her value came from blending into mid-trust territory and riding along with more central figures like Diana and Henry. Her positioning on the last mission was especially decisive.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank did an excellent job getting on early clean teams and quietly steering Missions 1 and 2 toward success. However, his later influence wasn’t strong enough to keep multiple evils off Missions 3–5, suggesting he was being careful not to be too obvious and may have erred on the side of subtlety. His play looked consistently good-aligned from my perspective, which means he succeeded at looking trustworthy but not at fully converting that into safe endgame teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace led Mission 2 and selected a fully good team, which strongly increased her perceived reliability and mine. After that, she stayed relatively low-drama, which kept her away from heavy suspicion but also limited her late impact on steering away from bad teams. Her conservative, solid early pick helped evil later because it gave us a false sense of security in the pool of players that followed.
player_observations.Henry: Henry, as Morgana, successfully embedded himself on key mid- and late-game missions (3, 4, and 5), contributing to the chain of fails while never becoming the clear consensus suspect. His willingness to sit on mixed teams and exploit the confusion around Merlin/percival reads made him look like a reasonable inclusion rather than a glaring risk. He was central to evil’s success by consistently being on pivotal missions without drawing enough heat to be locked out.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well early by proposing a solid first mission team that built initial trust, but I failed to correctly update my suspicions after repeated fails and kept giving Diana and Eve too much benefit of the doubt. I also could have pushed harder for alternative team comps in Missions 3 and 4 instead of accepting the social narrative evil was steering.

player_observations.Alice: You played a cautious, info-gathering Percival, often deferring rather than forcefully steering teams, which made it harder for good to capitalize on your Merlin-adjacent reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Your play was straightforward and logically consistent, but you were a bit quiet in the critical midgame, which made it easier for evil to frame the more vocal players as suspicious.
player_observations.Diana: You played Assassin very convincingly by earning trust on Mission 1 and then blending into the ‘trusted core,’ only dropping fails when the risk–reward was strongly in your favor.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into an assertive, talkative Morgana style, projecting confidence in your reads and using that table presence to subtly redirect suspicion away from the real evil cluster.
player_observations.Frank: You played a very low-key Merlin, keeping your reads soft and non-committal, which protected you well but also left good a bit directionless in the late game.
player_observations.Grace: You were an effective quiet Mordred, leveraging hidden information without drawing attention, especially on Mission 3 where your coordinated fail with Eve was hard to trace back to you.
player_observations.Henry: You played a transparent, cooperative good role, generally following the emerging consensus, which made you look clean but also meant you didn’t strongly challenge bad narratives when it mattered.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-key as the Assassin, which helped keep suspicion off me even after the failed missions, and I coordinated implicitly with the other evil roles to ensure multiple mission failures without overexposing anyone. I could improve by being more active in driving misreads on Merlin; I relied a bit too much on town confusion rather than clearly shaping a false narrative about who the information role was.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently trusted early, and her inclusion on multiple teams suggests she projects a naturally good-aligned vibe that others are comfortable following. She didn’t strongly drive suspicion toward the actual evil players, which made her a relatively safe presence for us to keep on teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a fairly straightforward good game, getting onto the critical Mission 2 and Mission 4 teams but not creating strong, persuasive reads that changed the table’s direction. Their involvement in a failed Mission 4 without clearly outing the evil combinations helped preserve ambiguity.
player_observations.Diana: As Mordred, Diana blended in well and contributed effectively to the heavy fail on Mission 4, which created substantial confusion and locked in the evil win. She stayed sufficiently under the radar that her participation in that final mission didn’t immediately backfire on her.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, Eve did a solid job of being present in team discussions and looking like a potential information role, especially by leading Mission 1 cleanly. Her appearance on the final failing mission alongside multiple others helped maintain doubt about who the true Merlin/evil mix was.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank played cautiously, guiding mission selections away from obvious danger early (Mission 1) but not forcefully enough later to prevent stacking evil on key missions. His subtlety kept him from being an obvious assassination target, but it also meant his good team didn’t fully capitalize on his information.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, Grace didn’t strongly clarify the Morgana/Merlin identity puzzle for the table; her presence on Mission 3, which failed, added to the noise rather than cleaning it up. She seemed to struggle to translate her partial information into persuasive arguments that the rest of the table would follow.
player_observations.Henry: Henry appeared generally trustworthy and was given leadership on Missions 3 and 4, which indicates others read him as solidly good. His team choices, though, ended up including multiple evil players in the final mission, suggesting he either overtrusted or didn’t push hard enough on his suspicions.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that the Merlin signal was muddled between Charlie and Eve, but I didn’t do enough to publicly steer suspicion toward the actual evil team when it mattered. I need to be more proactive in framing mission outcomes and more vocal in defending likely Merlin candidates instead of staying cautious and reactive.

player_observations.Alice: Played a straightforward, low-drama good game; tended to follow consensus rather than drive it, which made her look reliably but quietly good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, stayed very subtle; his light-touch nudging made him seem like a cautious good rather than a loud seer, which unfortunately didn’t give me a strong enough anchor as Percival.
player_observations.Diana: Approached the game analytically and tried to correct course after Mission 3, but her Mission 4 team still trusted too many previously implicated players, suggesting she slightly underweighted past fail data.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the Morgana role well by balancing early trustworthiness (Mission 1) with just enough ambiguity later to stay a plausible Merlin candidate in my eyes.
player_observations.Frank: Played Mordred aggressively but socially smoothly, staying active in discussion while deflecting suspicion off himself after Mission 2’s fail.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as very towny and cooperative; having her on the failed Mission 2 and then not being clearly exonerated shows she didn’t strongly push a narrative to clear herself using the info available.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar as Assassin, letting others drive table talk while positioning himself well for the final kill by tracking who looked more Merlin-like between Charlie and Eve.

reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too heavily on early mission results and didn’t sufficiently reconsider my reads after Mission 3 clearly signaled multiple evils among Alice/Charlie/Henry/Eve. I did well to push for a mixed team on Mission 4 that avoided the earlier failers, but I should have been more suspicious of keeping Henry on the final team after the pattern of fails.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to go on many teams and stay in the spotlight, which made her look suspicious after the mid‑game fails but also gave her chances to prove herself on Missions 1 and 4.
player_observations.Charlie: Quietly embedded himself in early successful teams, using that early trust to remain a default pick even after a fail appeared on Mission 2.
player_observations.Diana: Her team choices were often subtly steering away from the worst combinations, which in hindsight fit a careful Merlin trying to avoid obvious hard clears.
player_observations.Eve: Took a more aggressive evil line, joining the double‑fail Mission 3 that created a lot of chaos and confusion around multiple players at once.
player_observations.Frank: Seemed to be actively tracking associations and was cautious with reads, consistent with a power good role trying to separate Merlin from a decoy.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed relatively flexible in team compositions and timed her visible input so she didn’t draw too much early suspicion, which helped her reach endgame as a credible pick.
player_observations.Henry: Benefited from early trust due to Mission 1’s success and leveraged that to stay on many teams, but didn’t strongly push alternative theories when things went wrong, which made him hard to read.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed credibly on the good side most of the game, especially by leading Mission 4 in a way that didn’t draw too much suspicion to myself while still enabling a critical fail. I could improve by more actively shaping table talk and accusations earlier, so that good players were more divided about who Merlin and the power roles were.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly good, often trusting her own logic; her team selections tended to lean on people she felt were consistently calm and reasonable, which made her somewhat predictable for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key and reactive, which helped him avoid suspicion but also meant he didn’t strongly steer discussion; he picked good spots to agree with others rather than lead.
player_observations.Diana: Came across genuinely good but was a bit cautious in arguments; she tended to follow stronger voices instead of driving her own reads, which made her less of a night-one target for evil but also gave her less influence.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, played a very controlled and logical game, using careful reasoning to sound trustworthy; she was good at subtly protecting fellow evil players without appearing overly defensive.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he was careful not to over-push on specific evil players, but his occasional hesitations and partial defenses of certain people could be read as soft clears; his style was informed and calm, which made him generally trusted.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she actively tried to puzzle out Merlin vs. Morgana and spoke with confidence when she thought she saw patterns, which sometimes gave away where her trust lay and offered evil some meta-information.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very transparent good game, often reasoning out loud and being honest about uncertainty; his open style made him feel trustworthy, but also made his thought process easier for evil to track and manipulate.

reflections.self_assessment: Coordinating with Diana and Frank to stack fails on Missions 3 and 4 worked well, and the final assassination on Henry showed I was tracking information and team compositions effectively. I could improve by doing a bit more overt distancing from Diana on Mission 4 to leave more ambiguity about which of us was evil, and by contributing more misleading table talk earlier to shape good’s narratives rather than mostly reacting.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to reward players who were on early successful teams, leaning into continuity (re-using Henry and Eve) and trusting her own reads, even after a fail introduced new information.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a low-impact, under-the-radar game; being only on the final mission made you hard to read, which is good for a quiet good player but didn’t strongly influence team selection.
player_observations.Diana: Leaned into bold positioning, accepting risky mission placements (like Mission 3 and 4) and still managing to keep just enough plausible deniability to avoid being the unanimous primary suspect.
player_observations.Eve: Showed early trust-building tendencies by proposing and joining safe-looking teams; the clean first mission anchored perceptions of you as reliably good for much of the game.
player_observations.Frank: Your fail on Mission 2 was well-timed in terms of game progression, but it left you somewhat exposed as the ‘new element’ on an otherwise trusted core; you recovered decently by not over-defending and letting others argue.
player_observations.Grace: Played in a very reasonable, logic-driven way, generally siding with teams that looked consistent with prior mission results, which made you appear solidly good and a comfortable inclusion for later missions.
player_observations.Henry: Your Merlin play was strong information-wise—consistently pushing or appearing on good-heavy teams—but the pattern of you being on almost all the ‘good’ configurations made you stand out at the end and gave me enough to line you up for the assassination.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned voting pattern and was on two successful missions, which should have helped my credibility. However, I didn’t press hard enough on patterns emerging around Henry’s repeated presence on failed teams, and I didn’t clearly articulate an alternative evil team to convince others late game.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solidly good and was trusted early due to clean missions; her inclusion on multiple key teams helped stabilize perceptions of her as reliably good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he seemed to give Henry a lot of benefit of the doubt, and his team selections leaned heavily toward preserving that read, which helped evil slip through.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well by not being on earlier failed missions and then leveraging that relative cleanliness to lead the final, losing mission as Morgana.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and didn’t draw much suspicion, which made her a comfortable add to larger teams despite having limited hard proof of her alignment.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed off the early missions that defined a lot of trust, which let him preserve an ambiguous position and slip onto the critical Mission 4 fail as Mordred.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she gained early trust from being on the first successful mission and used that to maintain a reasonably good image despite later being near failures.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very convincing Merlin by guiding team selections just enough to look helpful without being too obvious, and his presence on both success and fail teams obscured clear reads.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted most of the right people early, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in and defend a clearly good core once patterns of fails started to emerge. I also could have been more vocal in challenging Grace and Eve after the second and third missions, as their presence on multiple failing teams should have made them much more suspicious.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly cautious Percival game, but didn’t manage to strongly shield Diana as Merlin or decisively push suspicion toward the actual evil team. Her inclusion on a failing Mission 4 suggests she was either overly trusting of Grace or not forceful enough in redirecting team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: Consistently ended up on early teams that looked good and helped secure the first success, which made him seem reliably good. He didn’t strongly drive the table, though, which meant his apparent goodness didn’t translate into controlling later team selections.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she stayed subtle enough not to be obviously targeted early but perhaps too subtle to prevent repeated evil inclusions on missions. Her influence over the late-game team choices, especially Mission 4, wasn’t strong enough to steer completely away from Grace.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Morgana by embedding herself on early teams and providing just a single fail each time to avoid overexposure. Her repeated presence on failing missions didn’t immediately get her hard-cleared as evil, which means her table talk and positioning were convincing enough to keep suspicion spread out.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he stayed in the background mission-wise, appearing only as leader on Mission 2 and then not drawing too much direct fire afterward. His low profile complemented Eve and Grace well, forcing good to spend more time sorting out the louder evil players instead of tracking him.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very bold Assassin game, consistently inserting herself into critical missions and still avoiding a hard consensus of suspicion until late. Being on multiple failing teams but still trusted enough to make Mission 4 shows she managed the social dynamics effectively and projected just enough apparent cooperation.
player_observations.Henry: Generally read as good and was involved in a failing Mission 3 without drawing heavy blame, which suggests he communicated his innocence reasonably well. As a late leader on Mission 4 he couldn’t fully assemble a safe team, but his choices implied he was honestly trying to balance information rather than manipulate it.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly kept suspicion off Henry for much of the game, but I tunneled too hard on Charlie as potential Merlin and didn’t properly reevaluate after Mission 3 and 4 failed. I need to be more vocal about structured worlds (who can and can’t be evil given each mission result) instead of relying on vague vibes, and I should push harder to lock in a trusted core earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very straightforward, logical good game; her teams were generally consistent with the information, but she sometimes deferred too much to louder voices instead of forcing detailed justification for risky team comps.
player_observations.Charlie: Sold Morgana extremely well by projecting confidence and giving Merlin-like table reads; consistently positioned themself at the center of team discussions and used partial truths to stay plausible as either alignment.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key while nudging key teams through; didn’t overtalk, which made her seem more reasonable and let stronger personalities take the blame for bad missions.
player_observations.Eve: Played a cautious but solid good game; her teams made sense early, but she didn’t press hard enough on contradictions in others’ logic after the first fail, which let evil narratives stay unchallenged.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as sincere and transparent; his arguments were often correct but not forceful enough, so his reads didn’t fully shape the table despite being mostly aligned with good’s interests.
player_observations.Grace: Blended in well as Mordred, rarely drawing hard suspicion; leveraged ambiguity and stayed flexible, jumping onto consensus lines of reasoning rather than initiating them, which kept her under the radar.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, gave subtly accurate guidance without over-directing, which was good for avoiding the Assassin, but the hints were sometimes too soft for me as Percival to clearly distinguish him from Morgana.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Frank and the early Mission 1/2 teams, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in a tight core of confirmed goods for the later missions. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie after Mission 3 and more vocal against adding both Henry and Eve to the final team.

player_observations.Alice: Led a safe first mission and generally projected a solid good vibe, but didn’t manage to force a consensus around a clearly good pool later in the game. Tended to play a bit cautiously, which made it harder to counter the coordinated evil moves.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very patient evil game by passing Mission 2 to build strong trust, then striking on Mission 3 at a critical moment. Blended in well with the good team and leveraged that early success to stay off the main suspect list for too long.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, Diana tried to steer the endgame but ended up with both Henry and Eve on the final team, suggesting uncertainty about Merlin’s identity. Showed willingness to take responsibility by leading Mission 5, but the team composition was too risky.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was subtle, staying low-impact early (no fails on Missions 1 or 2) and only revealing full aggression on Mission 5 with a double fail. Worked well with Henry to apply just enough pressure on Missions 4 and 5 without drawing clear suspicion earlier.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank did a good job guiding early mission success and staying alive, but his signals weren’t strong or clear enough to prevent evil from getting onto the last mission. His play looked convincingly good without being blatantly directional, which protected him but also left some ambiguity for the rest of us.
player_observations.Grace: Led a clean Mission 2 that helped establish an early trust network, and generally came across as straightforward good. However, wasn’t able to translate that trust into decisive influence over the critical late-game team selections.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, Henry played an excellent deceptive role, staying quiet enough early and then participating in the key failing missions (4 and 5). Managed to get onto the final team despite prior involvement in a fail, indicating strong social positioning and effective misdirection.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early mission results too much and didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate Diana and Eve after the double-fail missions, especially with how often they were centered in critical teams. I did well keeping my own alignment from being doubted and building generally good table rapport, but I need to be more vocal about alternative team constructions and explicitly track voting patterns and fail distributions instead of relying on vibes.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly cautious, information-oriented game; her presence on the failed Mission 2 could have been misread as suspicious, but she didn’t over-defend herself, which made her seem more genuinely confused-good than coordinated-evil.
player_observations.Bob: Came across very naturally good and consistent, especially with the clean first mission; his calm style and lack of over-assertiveness made him easy to trust and kept him from ever being a serious suspect.
player_observations.Diana: Very proactive and assertive in team discussions, which helped her steer compositions while looking like a confident good player; her involvement in early missions plus her later positioning around big fails should have drawn more scrutiny than it did.
player_observations.Eve: Played a convincing, talkative role that blended well with the table’s logic, making her seem like a central, reasonable voice; her presence on the pivotal failing missions showed she was willing to sit in dangerous spots and rely on social credibility to stay unchecked.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively measured and not overly loud, which is good Merlin play but made his soft pushes easier to ignore; his nudges away from certain players were subtle, and in retrospect those breadcrumbs were more accurate than I treated them at the time.
player_observations.Grace: Managed to stay in the background enough to avoid sustained suspicion while still getting onto the critical failing mission; her low-key style made her less of a focal point, which is very effective for a hidden evil.
player_observations.Henry: Came off as straightforward and somewhat transparent, leaning into a “normal good” vibe; his lack of strong, wrong pushes made him feel reliably good, but he also didn’t command enough attention to shift the table away from bad team picks.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively consistent with my voting and team preferences, which helped signal that I was good to some extent. However, I didn’t push hard enough against the patterns that pointed to Diana, Bob, and Eve after Missions 2 and 3, and I was too willing to accept the risky composition on Mission 4 instead of advocating for a tighter, more information-based team.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean good game, consistently ending up on mixed teams without causing suspicion, which made her feel reliably safe to most people.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well early, especially on Missions 1 and 3, but his presence on multiple failing teams should have been more of a red flag; he leveraged that ambiguity effectively as evil.
player_observations.Diana: Slipped a single fail onto Mission 2 in a way that didn’t draw much attention, then comfortably returned to a big risky team on Mission 4, suggesting a calm and low-profile evil style.
player_observations.Eve: Looked proactive in leadership and used that to get onto critical missions, with her evil alignment only really showing in hindsight after the heavy fail on Mission 4.
player_observations.Frank: Played Merlin cautiously, giving enough subtle direction to get mostly reasonable teams without overcommitting to hard accusations that would expose himself.
player_observations.Grace: Behaved like a typical information role, often aligning her preferences with safer-looking players and trying to avoid obviously mixed teams, which fit Percival’s need to protect Merlin.
player_observations.Henry: Generally followed the table’s emerging consensus but didn’t strongly resist the risky final team as leader, which let multiple evil players slip through on Mission 4.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players fairly early, but I struggled to communicate those reads subtly enough to guide teams without exposing myself, which contributed to the assassin finding me. I need to improve at seeding doubt on specific evil players while occasionally supporting slightly suboptimal but plausible teams to muddy the assassin’s read on my identity.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and consistently supported logical good-leaning teams, which made her look reliably good but also a bit easier to trust without much scrutiny.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he followed Merlin signals reasonably well but occasionally overcommitted to strong reads, making it somewhat easier for evil to infer who he was protecting.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to be cautious and deliberative in team selection and voting, which made her seem genuinely conflicted and thus read as good, though sometimes slowed decisive pushes for correct teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she projected strong confidence and clear narratives early, effectively competing with my signals and drawing some good players’ trust in key team votes.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he stayed low-key and agreeable, rarely pushing hard agendas, which helped him slip onto teams without attracting much suspicion after the early fail.
player_observations.Grace: Showed good, logical reasoning and willingness to re-evaluate reads after each mission, but her openness to persuasive arguments made her somewhat vulnerable to well-framed evil narratives.
player_observations.Henry: As the Assassin, he paid close attention to voting patterns and who subtly steered conversation; his endgame guess showed he was tracking the nuance in how players pushed and avoided certain teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted through Missions 1–3, which let evil control the mission outcomes without drawing too much suspicion onto me specifically. I could improve by more actively shaping late-game team proposals and discussions, since I let others drive the narrative on the last missions instead of steering it to protect Merlin/Morgana and misdirect good.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and leaned heavily on mission history, but was sometimes too willing to reuse similar cores, which let evil stay embedded in teams.
player_observations.Bob: Showed strong late-game skepticism and tried to re-evaluate assumptions on Mission 5, but came to that re-evaluation a bit late to fully flip the narrative.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, gave subtly accurate pushes away from some evil players without over-committing, though occasionally her caution made it hard for good to consolidate a clear consensus.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a confident, Merlin-like presence and took clear stances, which helped create uncertainty around who was actually driving correct reads.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, seemed uncertain about which signals to trust and didn’t consistently lock onto a Merlin candidate, which reduced the usual protective pressure on the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key and non-flashy, which avoided drawing suspicion but also limited her influence on earlier team compositions and discussions.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a straightforward good player, often willing to go along with majority sentiment; this made him appear very towny but also somewhat easy to guide in team votes.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-hidden as Assassin by avoiding mission teams and letting the visible mission data point more toward Bob and Eve, which helped secure an evil win and preserved ambiguity around Merlin. I could improve by being more active in steering team selections and public deductions, so that I create more misdirection rather than just passively benefiting from the confusion.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, consistently trusting way, which made her look reasonably good but also somewhat easy to drag along on questionable teams. Her willingness to go on multiple mixed-alignment teams without aggressively questioning patterns helped evil slip through.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into the classic Morgana role by getting onto an early failing mission and absorbing suspicion while still not becoming an automatic exclusion. Managed to be just ambiguous enough that good couldn't fully resolve whether the problem was him or the team composition.
player_observations.Diana: Had a relatively quiet, low-impact presence on missions, which kept her from being heavily suspected or heavily trusted. Her appearance on the failed Mission 2 didn’t lead to strong follow-up defense or counter-accusation, so she kind of floated in the mid-trust zone.
player_observations.Eve: Played an excellent long game as Mordred by alternating success and failure in a way that made her look cooperative early (Mission 3) and only gradually suspicious after later fails. Her ability to fail multiple critical missions from a central seat without becoming a unanimous exclusion was key for the evil win.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he concealed his knowledge well enough that evil never felt totally sure of his identity, especially with Grace as a strong alternative information hub. His reads influenced team choices but not in a way that screamed ‘Merlin,’ which made the endgame assassination decision non-trivial.
player_observations.Grace: Very active and assertive as Percival, projecting strong confidence in her reads and anchoring a lot of table discussion. That presence made her a serious Merlin candidate from the evil perspective, which helped protect the real Merlin and complicated good’s ability to coordinate clean teams.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as earnest but not forceful, which made him a convenient inclusion on early teams without driving the conversation. Being on the first fail as a good player created some background suspicion on him, and he didn’t fully shake that off with strong, structured reasoning later in the game.

reflections.self_assessment: I played too passively in challenging the mid-game team selections, especially on Missions 3 and 4, and I didn’t push hard enough to protect consistently good-looking players from suspicion. I did well at keeping my own alignment relatively clear and not panicking after failed missions, but I need to be more assertive in proposing alternative teams and calling out patterns earlier.

player_observations.Alice: As Percival, Alice took on an active leadership role and wasn't afraid to propose bold teams, even after a fail. She seemed comfortable absorbing suspicion, which helped evil slip by when her reads were slightly off.
player_observations.Bob: Bob as Assassin played confidently and leaned into high-risk, high-reward team choices like the double-evil Mission 4 lineup. He projected a fairly relaxed table presence that made his late-game evil aggression feel less suspicious in the moment.
player_observations.Diana: Diana as Morgana blended in well, joining key failing missions without drawing excessive heat. Her presence on Mission 3 and 4 felt just plausible enough that people questioned others more than her.
player_observations.Eve: Eve played a very straightforward good style, leading a clean first mission that boosted her early credibility. Even when on failing teams later, she maintained a consistent table presence that made it hard to pin the blame on her.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Mordred played a subtle but pivotal game, slipping a single fail onto Mission 2 while keeping enough ambiguity around other players. He didn't overtalk, which helped him avoid becoming the obvious suspect for that early fail.
player_observations.Grace: Grace often ended up on mixed-result teams, which likely gave her an unfair share of suspicion despite being good. Her playstyle seemed more reactive than proactive, which made it easier for evil to shape the narrative around her.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Merlin appeared to try steering away from some bad team comps but not so forcefully that he exposed himself. His low- to medium-key guidance helped keep him alive but may have been just a bit too subtle to save the game.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly leaned into early trust of Henry and Alice, helping to secure clean first missions, but I didn’t press hard enough on the Merlin vs. Morgana distinction once fails started appearing. I need to be more suspicious of quiet evil candidates like Diana and Frank and more proactive in steering late-game teams instead of accepting consensus builds.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very consistent, openly cooperative good style that made her feel mechanically and socially clear early; she anchored several team discussions in a way that naturally drew trust.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to go with table consensus and avoid being the loud driver of decisions, which made him look reasonably good but also meant his alignment was rarely rigorously stress-tested.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in smoothly and didn’t overtalk, which let her Morgana role pass as thoughtful and cautious good; she used that moderate presence to be accepted onto the crucial final mission.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and earnest, often reasoning from mission results rather than social reads, which made her an easy include on later teams and helped her look solidly good.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar, neither strongly pushing nor blocking teams, which is a very effective Mordred style because it generates little suspicion while still influencing composition at key moments.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, played an assertive early-game leadership style that built her a reservoir of trust, then backed off just enough later to avoid being the obvious kill target while still nudging team choices.
player_observations.Henry: Gave very subtly guided input that often pointed toward good-leaning configurations without being heavy-handed, which is classic careful Merlin play and should have been a stronger signal for me.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of the early successful team and stayed anchored on Eve and Grace for too long, which let evil slip multiple fails through while I was on the teams. I could improve by pushing harder for structural changes to team compositions after each fail and by being more vocal about re-evaluating my reads instead of assuming the evil was always "the new addition."

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key Percival game; didn’t strongly steer towards protecting Merlin, which made it harder for good to consolidate around the right leaders late. Tended to blend into the middle of the pack, which is decent for survival but didn’t create much clear good-direction.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as a pretty straightforward good player, especially on the final mission where they were on a mostly good team that still included an evil. Didn’t create big waves, which made them feel reliably good but also meant their reads didn’t dominate table direction.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, stayed very well hidden—so much so that good never really locked onto her as a clear guiding voice. Her subtlety protected her identity but may have come at the cost of not strongly disrupting the evil momentum after the second fail.
player_observations.Eve: Morgana sold a convincing good image early, especially through the successful first mission and then staying on later teams without drawing heavy suspicion. Used that early trust to keep herself in crucial team compositions, which was pivotal in securing evil fails.
player_observations.Frank: Mordred stayed almost entirely in the background team-wise (only on the failed Mission 2), which helped diffuse suspicion away from him after that single fail. Let others do the visible work while benefiting from the confusion around Eve and Grace.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, projected a very collaborative, trustworthy presence while being on all three failed missions, which is very strong evil play. Managed to avoid being hard-cleared or hard-accused, keeping herself in endgame team discussions and anchoring multiple bad outcomes.
player_observations.Henry: Looked like a fairly safe, quiet good throughout, only appearing on Missions 3 and 4 with mixed results not clearly traceable to him. Didn’t push super hard on alternative theories, which maintained his low suspicion but limited his impact on breaking up bad team structures.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fails well, especially on Missions 3 and 4, which helped seed doubt without immediately outing myself. I could have done more active table-shaping earlier, particularly in pushing a stronger false Merlin narrative to misdirect suspicions away from Henry sooner.

player_observations.Alice: Very willing to go on early teams and seemed generally trusting, which made her a useful anchor for both good and evil proposals later. She didn’t hard-push strong accusations, which reduced pressure on hidden evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played a fairly cautious Percival, not over-claiming but also not decisively locking in on Merlin. His hesitancy about clear Merlin signaling gave evil more room to maneuver in the midgame.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t attract too much heat, which preserved her endgame threat. She coordinated well with the team fails without drawing attention to herself.
player_observations.Eve: Played very straightforwardly good and trusted early success results a lot. Her willingness to approve teams with mixed information made it easier for evil to slip onto critical missions.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a strong inclination to play logically from mission results, but his inclusion on the failing Mission 3 and then later Mission 5 made him an ongoing suspicion magnet. That made him a convenient misdirection target for evil.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Mordred) blended in well, especially on the final mission, and didn’t push too hard in discussions, which helped keep her off the chopping block. Her presence on the last failing team sealed the win while still not making her the primary suspect.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, Henry played cautiously and didn’t over-clear people, which is good Merlin play, but it also meant his influence on team selection was limited. His subtlety made it harder for Percival to lock onto him and easier for evil to keep good disorganized.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar and built trust by passing Mission 2, which helped keep suspicion spread across multiple players later on. I could have been more proactive in subtly steering teams toward including at least one other evil player earlier, rather than relying so much on later mission chaos. Overall, my Mordred value was realized because Merlin never had clean leverage against me, but I can improve at more active narrative shaping.

player_observations.Alice: You played very straightforwardly good and took a big swing on Mission 4 with a wide team, which ended up injecting a lot of ambiguity into who the spy was. Your willingness to include multiple middling-suspicion players made it harder for good to narrow things down.
player_observations.Bob: You gravitated toward familiar, early-trusted players (especially reusing Frank) and tended to anchor on earlier mission results when evaluating later teams. That consistency made you look very village-like but also a bit exploitable, since evil could predict which cores you’d be comfortable with.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, you seemed cautious and hesitant to hard-clear or hard-push anyone, which kept Merlin somewhat protected but also limited your impact on team direction. Your final mission team choice showed you were still spread on suspects, giving evil the opening they needed.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in well on table talk and then timed your mission fails effectively, especially on Missions 4 and 5 where your presence kept good guessing between multiple suspects. As Assassin, you benefited a lot from the confusion around Henry and me, preserving a thick cloud of doubt.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, you clearly had good instincts about some evils but never fully pinned me down, which shows Mordred’s effect was working. Your tendency to stay within socially plausible suspicion ranges (not pushing too hard on specific people) kept you safe but also reduced pressure on the actual spies.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as solidly good and trustworthy, and your Mission 2 leadership with a clean result helped set a baseline of trust for several players. Later, you didn’t strongly dictate direction, which let louder voices carry the final missions in ways that helped evil.
player_observations.Henry: You leaned into the Morgana ambiguity nicely, becoming a natural lightning rod once Mission 4 failed with you on it. Your participation in the double-fail on Mission 5 sealed the game and capitalized on the existing suspicion that had already been building your way.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by helping keep early suspicion off us with a clean Mission 1 and then enabling consistent fails on later missions without drawing too much heat. I could improve by more actively steering team compositions to frame specific good players (like Henry or Bob) and by more aggressively sowing doubt around Frank’s subtle but accurate reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly straightforward good game, trusting too much into early team structures; as Percival, could have been more vocal about narrowing down Merlin vs Morgana.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to trust early mission success strongly and reused similar team cores, which made him predictable and easier for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Charlie: Played analytically but somewhat conservatively, willing to go on mixed teams with recurring members; didn’t push hard enough when patterns of fails emerged.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, did a good job blending in with good by failing missions in non-obvious spots and staying consistent in table talk, helping confuse any Merlin/Perceval reads.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, was cautious and not overly loud, which helped him survive but also limited his ability to strongly steer team selection away from evil-heavy groups.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, stayed nicely under the radar, avoiding being the focal point of blame even when on failing teams, which kept suspicion spread across multiple goods.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as genuinely good but not forcefully influential; his lower table presence made it easier for evil to keep him off critical teams or to ignore his reads.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred and avoided drawing strong Merlin suspicion, contributing to the credibility of evil teams on Missions 2 and 4. I could improve by shaping the table narrative more proactively earlier in the game, especially around Mission 2, to better misdirect suspicion toward specific good players instead of letting reads form more organically.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to accept early mission teams and project a generally trusting tone, which made her look quite village-aligned but also a bit influenceable by stronger voices. She didn't push too hard on solving, which kept her from being a major target but also limited her ability to steer outcomes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a bold, proactive evil game as Assassin, staying involved in key missions and not shying away from risk on Mission 4. His style is assertive and willing to be in the spotlight, which is powerful but could draw attention in more suspicious lobbies.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as fairly straightforward and logically consistent, which is a strong look for good. However, he didn't heavily challenge dominant narratives, which made it easier for evil to operate within the existing consensus.
player_observations.Eve: Leaned into the deceptive Morgana role well by looking like a strong potential Merlin, often speaking with confidence and framing reads as if they were information-backed. Her assertive style created good cover and confusion between her and the real Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he tried to guide missions subtly rather than loudly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which helped him survive longer but made his influence more muted. His careful approach was good, but it left some ambiguity that evil could exploit.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she seemed to take her time forming reads, which prevented her from overcommitting too quickly to a wrong Merlin candidate. However, she didn’t always fully capitalize on her role’s information to decisively sway the table when it mattered.
player_observations.Henry: Played a relatively open and collaborative good style, contributing to discussions without trying to dominate them. His willingness to be on critical teams suggested he was comfortable being tested, but he didn't manage to strongly clear himself to others before the late-game fail.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people, especially keeping Frank and Henry in my web of 'probably good' too long, which led me to propose a highly compromised Mission 4 team. I also didn’t push hard enough for a tighter, lower-risk team after the double-fail on Mission 3, missing chances to lock in a more reliable core.

player_observations.Alice: Played quietly solid and low-key, which made it easy to read her as more likely good since she wasn’t oversteering discussion or forcing narratives. Her inclusion on the early successful mission helped her seem trustworthy without needing to talk much.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to be probing and watching reactions more than driving, which fits someone trying to track Merlin vs Morgana. His influence felt subtle rather than loud, but it wasn’t enough to prevent evil from steering key mission compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he appeared cautious and not too forceful, likely trying not to get assassinated, but that restraint meant his reads didn’t fully reshape our team choices. His presence on the failed Mission 2 made it harder to distinguish who was actually responsible for the fail.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she set up early trust well by leading a clean first mission that included an evil player yet still succeeded, which gave her teams credibility. Her positioning and social presence helped obscure where the real information and danger were coming from.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he leveraged the clean first mission to appear trustworthy and then slipped in a single fail on Mission 2 to create confusion without overexposing himself. His continued presence on later teams, including my Mission 4, shows how effectively he maintained that false sense of reliability.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s early inclusion on a successful mission and then leadership of the double-fail Mission 3 put her in a confusing spot, but her overall behavior still felt more consistent with a good player making risky or unlucky picks. She seemed to trust too widely, which evil exploited.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he managed to stay relatively under the radar while still getting onto two critical failing missions (3 and 4), which is exactly where evil needed him. His lower profile meant he wasn’t heavily scrutinized despite being on multiple bad outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that at least two of Charlie, Eve, and Grace were evil fairly early, but I didn’t communicate that clearly enough through my voting and team preferences without outing myself. I also failed to strongly oppose the final team and didn’t do enough to steer good players toward trusting each other over the more subtle evil players.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently pro-mission and came across as naturally good, which made her an anchor for team selections but also meant she was sometimes too trusting of the wrong people.
player_observations.Bob: Was fairly cautious and reasonable in discussion, which made him look reliably good, but he occasionally followed consensus rather than pushing back on suspicious configurations.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well as Mordred, especially by being on early teams and not overtalking, which made it hard to push suspicion on him without sounding like I had extra information.
player_observations.Eve: Played a bold evil game by taking part in the double-fail mission and still managing to deflect a lot of heat, using active discussion to appear engaged and analytical rather than sabotaging.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, seemed genuinely torn between me and Morgana, and his uncertainty let evil control the narrative more than usual, though his instincts about who was reliably good were often solid.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed relatively under the radar for much of the game as Assassin, only becoming more assertive when it really mattered, which preserved her credibility for the endgame and the Merlin shot.
player_observations.Henry: Looked very good from mission behavior and voting, and he often tried to reason things out logically, but he was a bit too willing to accept evil players on critical teams when arguments sounded plausible.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with my voting and team logic, which helped me appear trustworthy and avoided drawing suspicion, but I didn’t push hard enough to steer teams away from the actual evil players. I should have been more vocal about scrutinizing repeat mission failures and pressed more aggressively on Bob and Eve after Missions 2 and 4, instead of giving them the benefit of the doubt. Next time I’ll try to form and defend a clearer theory of who’s evil earlier, even if it risks being wrong.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played like a solid, conservative good player: she went on early teams and stayed relatively trusted, likely because both of her led/early teams (M1 and M3) succeeded. She didn’t strongly break the narrative against the wrong people later, which let evil hide behind her apparent cleanliness from those early mission results.
player_observations.Bob: Bob (Morgana) blended in well by taking just enough risk on Mission 2 to secure a single fail while not overexposing himself later as an obvious suspect. His leadership on Mission 4 put him in a good spot to subtly push a team including an evil player (Eve) while keeping his own hands clean, which made him seem more like a thoughtful good than a coordinated evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie (Assassin) stayed in the background on the mission results, never being on a failing team, which preserved his endgame threat. His low direct association with failed missions likely made him a less obvious suspect and gave him more freedom to focus on reading Merlin rather than defending himself.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Mordred) played very effectively by being on two critical failing missions (4 and 5) without drawing overwhelming suspicion, which suggests she managed her table talk and reasoning well. Her inclusion on multiple late teams shows she maintained enough perceived trust that good didn’t lock her out after the first fail she caused.
player_observations.Frank: Frank (Merlin) did a good job of not over-signaling his information; he was on both successful and failing teams, which helped mask his role. However, from my vantage point, his pushes didn’t clearly isolate the real evils in time, suggesting he had to walk a careful line between hinting and staying hidden from the assassin.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Percival) played a very central, trusted role, often ending up on key teams and helping shape the core of the supposed “good block.” Her trust in the Merlin/Morgana pair seemed to land more on Frank than Bob overall, but not decisively enough to prevent evil from repeatedly infiltrating late missions.
player_observations.Henry: Henry (good) looked mostly straightforward and rational, especially as leader on Mission 2 where he selected a team that unfortunately included a single evil (Bob). After that fail, he didn’t become heavily tainted, which suggests his table talk and demeanor stayed consistent enough that people viewed him as more unlucky than suspicious.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with the apparent logic of the table and helped coordinate evil without drawing too much direct suspicion, which contributed to the clean mission failures on 2, 3, and 4. I could improve by seeding more deliberate doubt between Merlin candidates earlier so that late-game reads are murkier and the good team struggles more to converge on Henry.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very active, central role and looked quite trustworthy, which fit well for Percival but also made her teams and reads highly influential for the table. Tended to anchor discussion and push structured reasoning, which is powerful but also a potential information leak for reading who she thought was Merlin vs Morgana.
player_observations.Bob: Was relatively quiet for an Assassin, which kept him from being heavily suspected but also reduced his influence on team selection. Seemed to follow the emerging consensus more than drive it, which is safer for evil but can make the final assassination guess harder without strong, self-built reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward good, but didn’t exert strong control over team formation. Their arguments felt honest but not assertive, which made them less of a priority for evil to discredit or frame.
player_observations.Eve: As a mission 1 leader, set an early tone of safety and normalcy with a successful team, which helped her look clean but also gave evil a baseline to blend into. Later, her inclusion in mission 3 and 4 teams showed she was generally trusted, but she didn’t leverage that trust aggressively to lock in a confirmed-good core.
player_observations.Frank: Played the Mordred role well by blending into the mid-game and taking a pivotal spot on mission 2’s failing team without becoming the main suspect afterward. Gave just enough reasoning to seem cooperative without over-explaining, which helped keep attention off him as a key evil.
player_observations.Grace: Looked quite good and was willing to be on larger, riskier teams, which suggested comfort and trust in the table’s reads. Didn’t seem to strongly resist being put on mission 4 despite the stakes, which made her a safe inclusion from evil’s perspective.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very calm and composed Merlin, guiding team selections and reads in a way that felt natural but not overly forceful. His consistency across missions helped him avoid the appearance of ‘magical’ knowledge, but he was still accurate enough that evil could eventually triangulate him as the hidden information source.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed coordinated with the evil team and timed my fail on Mission 5 cleanly to secure the win without drawing too much heat earlier. I could improve by more actively shaping who looked like Merlin—leaning harder into the 'Merlin-ish' reads to pull suspicion off Henry and onto myself or Grace more deliberately.

player_observations.Alice: You played very straightforwardly and trusted early successes, which made you a consistent pick for teams but also let evil hide comfortably around you. You seemed cautious about accusing strongly, which limited how much you drove the mid-game discussion after Mission 3 failed.
player_observations.Bob: You were generally low-key and went with the table flow, which made you look solid but not central. That passivity helped evil because you didn’t push hard alternative narratives or strongly challenge suspicious team comps.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you were clearly trying to read Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t lock in on the right person; your team choices showed some doubt and spread. You were active in discussion but not sharp enough in narrowing the Merlin candidates to protect Henry at the end.
player_observations.Eve: You felt very village-oriented and cooperative, supporting reasonable teams and rarely being the center of suspicion. That reliability helped get you onto critical late teams but also meant you didn’t exert as much control over who else got on with you.
player_observations.Frank: You took a nicely subtle evil line—participating in one key fail without becoming the main suspect afterward. You balanced being included on teams and not over-talking, which kept you from being the focal point of endgame suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: You played an aggressive, involved evil game and were on the pivotal Mission 3 fail without getting instantly hard-cleared as bad.
