Your talkative style created enough noise that it was harder for good to cleanly isolate where the information was coming from, though you could have leaned even more into a Merlin-like posture to mislead Charlie.
player_observations.Henry: You had strong, accurate reads typical of Merlin and guided early team selections well, especially in getting clean early missions. However, you were just visible enough in steering that we could identify you as likely Merlin by endgame, suggesting you could have hidden your knowledge slightly better behind other players’ opinions.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players fairly early, but I failed to communicate that information in a way that guided team selection without making myself an obvious Merlin target. I need to be subtler in how I steer votes and team compositions, especially when evil is split across different missions and can hide behind mostly successful early teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious Percival, seemed genuinely torn between Eve and me as Merlin and didn’t push her suspicions aggressively, which gave evil more room to maneuver.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively low-key and agreeable, often going along with consensus rather than driving it, which made him look safely good but not especially influential in correcting bad team picks.
player_observations.Charlie: Felt solidly good throughout: consistent logic, supportive of reasonable teams, and didn’t overreact to mission outcomes, which helped build trust but also made it easier for evil to blend in around him.
player_observations.Eve: Sold the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well, staying calm under suspicion and leaning into just enough ‘good logic’ to keep Percival and others doubting without overcommitting to any one narrative.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a quieter, more background role, letting others talk while subtly nudging votes and teams, which kept suspicion off him even after fails started to appear.
player_observations.Grace: Balanced aggression and restraint effectively; as Assassin she stayed just suspicious enough to be questioned but not enough to be widely rejected from teams, and read the Merlin pool well in the endgame.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as sincerely good with straightforward reasoning, but was sometimes too trusting of mixed teams after single fails, which helped evil sneak onto critical missions without heavy resistance.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile early, which helped keep suspicion off me and allowed evil to coordinate the pivotal fails on Missions 3–5. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around who looked Merlin, since even though evil won, I relied more on mission outcomes than on deliberate social manipulation to drive votes.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission success too much and carried that trust forward, which made her more resistant to revising reads after the first fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played a classic Percival game by strongly protecting his Merlin reads, but his visible defense patterns gave hints about who he thought the power roles were.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, blended in well with good by being consistently proactive about team suggestions and using mission logic to appear transparent.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and leaned on consensus rather than pushing strong independent reads, which made her less of a target but also less influential.
player_observations.Frank: Relied heavily on mission results over social cues, which made his suspicions lag one step behind the evolving information.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, stayed nicely under the radar and let others drive most of the debate, which helped keep heat off the evil team composition.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, tried to guide team selections subtly, but the pattern of who he pushed for and against became noticeable over multiple missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on suspecting Bob and Frank together after Mission 3’s single fail, which made me discount the possibility that Henry and Charlie were coordinated evil and misread Frank’s subtle Merlin signaling. I need to be more deliberate about tracking who is trying to preserve flexible team options vs. who is aggressively locking in certain narratives, and I should have pushed harder for a safer composition on Mission 5 instead of compromising with multiple unknowns.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and felt transparently good, but her leadership on Mission 4 ended up mixing too many uncertain players, which obscured information and gave evil room to hide.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently landed on early teams and looked very trustworthy, but his inclusion in almost every critical team made it hard to separate genuine trust from him being unintentionally used as cover for evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well and let others drive the table talk; as Mordred, he avoided being a focal point and benefitted from not being loudly wrong or right, which made him feel like a safe mid-pack pick.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet and avoided sharp stances, which kept suspicion low; as Assassin, she positioned herself well to remain team-viable until the endgame and to have good Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he played very cautiously and didn’t hard-push against specific evils, which protected his identity but also left good without enough strong guidance on the final team.
player_observations.Grace: Felt solidly good, especially around her Mission 2 leadership, but her later support patterns didn’t decisively narrow down the evil candidates, keeping the mid-game foggier than it needed to be.
player_observations.Henry: Did an excellent job as Morgana by mirroring a ‘quietly insightful good’ style—he made just enough reasonable suggestions to appear helpful while subtly steering key missions into dangerous lineups.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by helping spread suspicion across multiple good players and ensuring key missions had enough evil presence to fail reliably. I could improve by more clearly manipulating team compositions earlier so that endgame suspicion focused less on Frank and Alice, making the final Merlin read harder for good.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and tended to join mixed teams, which fit well with a Percival trying to hedge between Merlin candidates; didn’t push hard, which made her seem middle-of-the-pack in suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Was consistently included early and passed both missions he joined, giving him a very clean record and a quiet kind of trust that others seemed to accept without much challenge.
player_observations.Charlie: As a frequent early leader and team member, Charlie’s teams looked mostly safe, but the fail on Mission 2 attached some lingering doubt; still, his overall tone seemed more collaborative than accusatory.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced aggression and subtlety as Assassin: joined the key failing missions without drawing overwhelming blame, and managed to stay in enough successful-appearing structures to remain a plausible good player.
player_observations.Frank: Played a low-key Merlin game, not over-directing team choices, which made his identity less obvious; his caution protected him for a while but also let evil shape some mission compositions uncontested.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed in the background and let others take the visible leadership and blame, which fit Mordred well; her low-profile presence on a key fail helped ensure evil influence without triggering direct suspicion.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforward and relatively transparent, which made him feel like a default-trusted good; his lack of direct involvement in fails limited the pressure placed on him.

reflections.self_assessment: Staying clean on the early missions worked well, letting other evil players take the blame while I preserved ambiguity around my role. I could have done more to subtly steer suspicion toward Merlin/Grace earlier instead of relying so heavily on Diana and Bob’s visible fails to carry the endgame. Next time I should speak up more in team discussions to actively shape narratives rather than mostly benefiting from others’ mistakes.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be included frequently and accepted that trust, which made her look suspicious by association with multiple fails even though she was good. She seemed relatively open to going on teams and less focused on aggressively solving, which made her an easy ‘background’ suspect without strong defense.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very aggressive evil game, taking responsibility for key fails and staying in the center of mission decisions. His willingness to be on repeated critical teams created strong swing potential but also risked drawing late-game suspicion if the game had gone to an assassination decision.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off as fairly low-impact and somewhat quiet in terms of driving team composition, which made them a safe person to keep in a gray area. Being on mixed-result teams without strongly pushing narratives kept them from becoming a prime clear or a prime suspect.
player_observations.Diana: Boldly failed early and late missions, embracing a high-impact Mordred style that put pressure on the good team’s trust structure. Despite that, she managed to avoid becoming the sole scapegoat for the early fail, which helped keep confusion alive about who was actually evil.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he positioned himself on and around critical teams but didn’t manage to consistently keep evil off lineups, especially later. His reads seemed partially accurate but not forceful enough to stop multiple-evil teams from being approved.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, her mission 3 team choice showed some misreads, especially in trusting Bob, which helped evil stay embedded in key lineups. She seemed active in shaping teams but not fully confident in separating Merlin/Morgana, which worked heavily in my favor.
player_observations.Henry: As a good leader on the final mission, he placed trust in multiple evil players and approved a very risky lineup that sealed the game. His leadership style leaned toward compromise and inclusion rather than hardline suspicion, which evil could exploit to stack the final team.

reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into my Merlin-like image effectively, letting Charlie take most of the spotlight while I supported his narratives instead of competing with them, which helped keep suspicion off the real Merlin. I could improve by planting more deliberate, traceable 'good' logic early that later justifies my pushes on specific teams, so my influence looks more like consistent town reasoning than opportunistic steering.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and was willing to repeat early trusted cores, which made her a stabilizing presence but also a bit easier to park on teams without heavy scrutiny. She didn’t force many hard accusations, which kept her safe but limited her impact on team direction.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he clearly tried to read between Charlie and me, often deferring to stronger table consensus instead of forcing his own Merlin-read. His caution helped evil because he didn’t hard-clear or hard-push either of us, leaving ambiguity about who was Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he guided missions subtly rather than with loud, domineering control, which made his reads look like ‘good instincts’ instead of confirmed information. This lower-key style protected him somewhat, but also allowed evil teams to slip through when the table didn’t fully buy into his preferences.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a methodical good player, focusing on mission results and composition patterns rather than gut reads or bold gambits. Her leadership on Mission 4 was fairly consensus-driven, which made it easier for evil to ride along without being singled out.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he blended very well with the logical core of the table, especially around Missions 1 and 2, using reasonable arguments that matched how a thoughtful good player would talk. He avoided overclaiming influence, which kept his alignment opaque and let him be included on critical teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace came across as flexible and cooperative, often open to being on teams and adjusting based on others’ arguments instead of strongly anchoring her own narratives. That made her seem approachable and non-threatening, which helped evil keep her in the mix while attention went elsewhere.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he stayed relatively low-profile but reliably backed lines that maintained uncertainty about Merlin’s identity, which is exactly what evil needed. His contributions didn’t draw spotlight, leaving him well-positioned for the endgame decision without having been heavily interrogated throughout the match.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie and Grace to keep suspicion spread across multiple good players, and Mission 3’s double-fail was timed nicely to generate maximum confusion without fully outing all evils. I could improve at more actively shaping the Merlin/percival narrative mid-game—Diana stayed relatively under pressure but not enough for a serious late-game assassin angle—and I should have done more vocal distancing on teams that failed so my involvement looked more reluctant than driving.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early success heavily and anchored on Henry as consistently good, which made her more willing to repeat familiar cores; she didn’t aggressively re-open assumptions after Mission 3’s double-fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played conservatively and followed the table’s consensus more than driving it, especially visible in late-game team construction where he leaned on previously ‘safe’ names rather than pushing new hypotheses.
player_observations.Charlie: Very proactive as Mordred, comfortable being on early teams and absorbing suspicion after the first fail; used that to protect others by making himself a plausible, self-contained evil explanation.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious about hard-pushing specific evils, which kept her alive but also meant her influence over team selection was more subtle than decisive; she nudged, rather than steered.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he did some Merlin-hunting but never solidified a strong public read, which made his defense of Diana somewhat muted and limited the information-good gained from his perspective.
player_observations.Grace: Played Assassin very patiently, allowing other evils to take front-facing blame on failed missions; stayed relatively low-key, preserving flexibility for the endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: Consistently read as trustworthy and leaned into that image, accepting spots on many teams without strongly challenging the logic behind them; his steady presence helped us hide among his ‘safe’ aura.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred and avoided drawing strong Merlin suspicion, which helped evil keep flexibility going into the later missions. I could improve by being more proactive in subtly steering team compositions earlier, especially on Mission 2 and 3, to create more conflicting information and suspicion around the good players.

player_observations.Alice: Played very "standard good"—cautious but generally trusting of the early team structures, which made her seem reliably towny and a frequent include on teams.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into a slightly risky, assertive style that fit Morgana well, projecting confidence in reads even when they were wrong, which helped muddy perceptions of who the information roles might be.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed reasonably low-key for an assassin, not forcing the spotlight but stepping in with firm opinions when it mattered later, preserving flexibility for the final Merlin guess.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as sincerely good but a bit quieter in shaping team proposals, which made her easier to place on teams without generating much discussion about her alignment.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very controlled, information-driven game that in retrospect clearly reflected Merlin—careful about overcommitting but often subtly nudging away from fully evil-heavy teams.
player_observations.Grace: Showed classic Percival behavior by strongly trying to interpret and protect the perceived information roles, which sometimes caused her to be a stabilizing presence on teams.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a direct, straightforward good-playstyle, especially on Mission 2, but didn’t always capitalize on his credibility to strongly challenge later, more suspicious team configurations.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well tracking mission results and narrowing evil candidates after each fail, especially noticing overlapping suspects like Frank and Diana. I could improve by pushing my suspicions more assertively in team discussions and being clearer about why certain combinations (like Bob+Diana) were too risky late-game, instead of going along with compromises to keep consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very proactive info-gathering role, often steering team discussions in a way that fit Percival trying to protect Merlin; occasionally seemed a bit too trusting of certain risky team comps.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to stay just active enough in discussion to appear helpful, which made his late-game leadership on a double-fail team look like plausible bad luck rather than clearly evil until after the fact.
player_observations.Charlie: Low-profile and fairly cautious, contributing some logic but rarely driving decisions, which made it hard to confidently read them as good during the game.
player_observations.Diana: Balanced aggression and reason well, often framing arguments in a convincing way that helped hide her as Morgana, especially when she was on mixed teams with trusted players.
player_observations.Frank: Played a strong undercover role as Mordred by blending in with reasonable logic and not overtalking, making the single-fail second mission look like it could have come from multiple sources.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as genuinely trying to solve the puzzle, with fairly transparent reasoning, which read as good but perhaps didn’t push back hard enough on suspicious team builds.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, did a good job not being too obvious, but at times their caution about certain players wasn’t forcefully articulated enough to clearly steer the table away from stacked-evil teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and tried to stay consistent in my voting so I wouldn’t look suspicious, which helped me avoid being falsely targeted as evil. However, I could have been more vocal in pushing concrete theories and challenging the assumptions around the later mission teams, especially after Mission 3 failed. Next time I should track voting patterns and team compositions more rigorously so I can argue more convincingly for or against specific players.

player_observations.Alice: Alice generally seemed steady and trustworthy, especially with being on early successful missions, which made it hard to seriously suspect her later. She didn’t overtalk, which helped her blend in as a safe pick for teams.
player_observations.Bob: Bob came across as relatively low-profile and agreeable, which made him an easy inclusion on teams without raising alarms. His lack of strong accusations or defenses made it harder to read his alignment clearly.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie was active in discussion and seemed to take on a semi-leadership role, especially around mid-game team building. His confidence in some players influenced the table a lot, which in hindsight helped evil steer team compositions.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played a very smooth, subtle game, rarely drawing direct suspicion even when things started going wrong. She was good at sounding reasonable about team selections while still keeping just enough ambiguity to avoid being pinned down.
player_observations.Frank: Frank stayed somewhat under the radar and didn’t push major narratives, which made him easy to overlook as a potential source of sabotage. His quiet style worked well with the chaos in the later missions, where attention was focused on louder players.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s early leadership and presence on the first successful mission made her look quite safe for a long time. She balanced talking enough to seem engaged without giving away much about her actual decision-making process.
player_observations.Henry: Henry appeared logical and consistent in his reasoning, which made him a strong voice in shaping who felt trustworthy. Because he sounded so put-together, it was easy to lean on his reads, which ended up heavily influencing how teams were formed.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well blending into the early mission teams, especially passing Mission 1 to build trust and then participating in the first fail to start shifting suspicion away from myself and other evils. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin/percival narrative mid-to-late game, explicitly seeding doubt about Diana and making myself look more like a strong, vocal good player so that evil has clearer endgame assassination options.

player_observations.Alice: Played like a cautious information-gatherer, often trying to reconcile mission results with known claims, which fit a typical Percival pattern of trying to sort Merlin from Morgana without overcommitting.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed generally trusting and went along with emerging table consensus, contributing more with votes than with assertive team-building, which made them look like a solid but not highly vocal good.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and relatively consistent, accepting early teams and not overreacting to single fails, suggesting a more logic-first approach rather than heavy social reads.
player_observations.Diana: Played a subtle Merlin game, avoiding loud hard clears or hard accusations, instead nudging suspicion via questions and soft preferences for certain lineups, which kept her from being an obvious assassination target.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, did a good job staying out of the spotlight and letting others drive the narrative, quietly inserting themselves into critical teams without drawing strong blame afterward.
player_observations.Grace: Leaned into a proactive, assertive style as Assassin, ready to back risky teams and push narratives, which helped evil steer late-game perceptions and set up a favorable assassination landscape.
player_observations.Henry: Approached team selection pragmatically, appearing to weigh prior mission data and table sentiment when leading, which made him look consistently good-aligned and relatively trustworthy to others.

reflections.self_assessment: I over-trusted the consistent early-team core (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Henry) after Missions 1 and 2, and didn’t push hard enough to reshuffle that block once Mission 3 failed. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie’s central positioning and advocated more strongly for lineups that deliberately excluded him and stress-tested alternative good cores.

player_observations.Alice: Alice was very willing to go on repeated teams and seemed comfortable staying in the core, which made her look reliably good even when failures started appearing. Her willingness to continue teaming with Charlie despite the Mission 3 fail helped evil maintain credibility in that block.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, Bob clearly trusted the wrong signal and anchored heavily around Charlie, which dragged a lot of good players’ trust along with him. His confidence and insistence on keeping the same core made it harder for the table to pivot away from the poisoned Merlin read.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie (Morgana) played a strong central social game, positioning himself in almost every important team and keeping just enough consistency to look like a safe anchor. He leveraged the early mission successes to build a trusted image, then allowed key fails at pivotal moments without drawing decisive suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Diana as Assassin stayed relatively low-impact after the early successful leadership, which kept her from being heavily suspected even when later missions failed. Her early successful mission as leader helped seed long-term credibility for the evil team structure.
player_observations.Frank: Frank, despite being good, ended up on the critical failing Mission 3 team, which likely shook his own and others’ confidence in alternative configurations. He didn’t manage to push a strong counter-narrative later to break the trust in the main core that included Charlie.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Mordred) played a more in-the-background role but benefited greatly from the entrenched trust in the Alice/Bob/Charlie block. Being brought onto the final mission while that core was still largely trusted allowed her to participate in the decisive fail without having attracted much heat beforehand.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Merlin struggled to steer the table away from the Charlie-centered core, likely trying to avoid being too obvious and getting assassinated. His subtlety gave evil room to maintain control of team composition, especially in the mid-to-late missions where a more forceful redirection might have flipped outcomes.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated effectively with Charlie and Henry to stack late-game mission fails and maintained a believable good façade through Missions 1 and 2, which helped us avoid early suspicion. I could improve by seeding more nuanced, proactive suspicion on non-Merlin players earlier, to make the final assassination decision feel less obvious and more naturally justified in table talk.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and leaned on consensus, often supporting teams that felt 'safe' rather than driving her own reads, which made her look generically good but not strongly insightful. Her leadership on Mission 4 seemed more about covering bases than pushing a strong theory, which made it easier for evil to slip onto the team.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to trust prior successful teams heavily, which made him slow to revise reads even after Mission 3 failed. His willingness to repeatedly go with similar cores gave evil a comfortable structure to hide in.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, blended into the background well and avoided drawing direct heat, especially after Mission 3’s fail where suspicion could have turned toward him more strongly. He let others drive major arguments, which helped keep his own alignment relatively opaque.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she showed some protectiveness over certain players but didn’t clearly or forcefully translate that into public Merlin-protection logic. Her Mission 5 team felt like an attempt to balance risk and info but ended up giving evil the window they needed.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he guided team selection subtly rather than loudly, nudging toward safer configurations without over-claiming certainty, which was good discipline. However, his slight pattern of de-prioritizing specific evil players on critical teams gave just enough of a trail for me to identify him as Merlin in the end.
player_observations.Grace: Played straightforwardly good, generally following logical voting patterns and not overcomplicating the read structure. Her Mission 2 leadership was conservative and reasonable, which helped build trust in her but also reassured evil that we could pass early without much scrutiny.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he took on a more active, opinionated role, which helped muddy the Merlin/percival information dynamic and created plausible alternative ‘wise’ voices. His participation in the failed missions was timed well, maintaining just enough doubt so that he didn’t become the default evil read.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that evil was concentrated among Diana, Eve, and Grace after Missions 2 and 3, but I didn’t communicate that suspicion subtly enough for good to coordinate around it. I need to improve at nudging teams away from multiple evils without making my knowledge as Merlin too obvious, and at protecting myself from an accurate assassination even when the evils are struggling early.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious good role, usually comfortable joining popular team proposals, which made you appear reliably towny but also a bit passive in shaping team comps.
player_observations.Bob: Your early clean mission and willingness to repeat core teams made you look consistently good, but you didn’t push hard enough to interrogate why later missions with overlapping players started failing.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed analytical and focused on card counts and overlaps, but you were a bit too trusting of recurring team structures, which let evil hide in familiar lineups.
player_observations.Diana: You blended in well early by going on the first successful mission and then shifting into more assertive leadership later, which helped you steer teams while keeping suspicion spread out.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into a confident, talkative style that fit Morgana well, convincingly mirroring Merlin-like reasoning and creating real ambiguity for Percival and the rest of the table.
player_observations.Grace: You stayed relatively under the radar despite being on a big failing mission, using a lower-profile style that let louder players draw most of the heat for bad outcomes.
player_observations.Henry: You played like a straightforward good: open, not overly paranoid, and willing to trust prior mission results, which helped evil because you didn’t strongly challenge suspicious patterns in team selection.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Diana and Eve were likely evil relatively early based on their team preferences and how they reacted to mission results, but I struggled to communicate those suspicions subtly enough without overly exposing myself as Merlin. I also put too much trust in Bob after Mission 1's clean result, which let evil steer critical teams later; in future games I should more clearly differentiate between 'temporarily safe' and 'genuinely trusted' players in my voting and soft signals.

player_observations.Alice: Played consistently cautious but generally pro-mission, which made her look reliably good and a natural core for many teams; she didn’t push strong accusations, which kept her from being targeted much by evil.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in very well as evil by riding the credibility from the clean first mission and then quietly influencing later team compositions; his assassin positioning seemed deliberate, staying just active enough to be informed without drawing heavy suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as earnest and reasonably logical, but wasn’t always forceful in pushing his reads, which made it easier for evil to ignore or override him in later team debates.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very controlled and low-friction Mordred game, passing in Mission 2 only once and then leaning on social trust rather than loud arguments, which helped her avoid becoming a focal point of suspicion until it was too late.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she projected a confident, information-rich style that mimicked a power role well, which likely muddied the waters for Grace/Percival and helped confuse good about where the real information was coming from.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she tried to anchor around perceived information sources, but seemed pulled between competing Merlin candidates, which diluted the impact of her influence on team selection.
player_observations.Henry: Showed a cooperative and reasonably transparent thought process, but in Mission 4 ended up on a heavily evil-stacked team, suggesting he either over-trusted vocal players or deferred too much in a critical decision spot.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil, especially by keeping Mission 1 clean and then using my leadership on Mission 2 to slip in a single, believable fail. I could improve by more actively shaping the Merlin narrative mid-to-late game, as I leaned a bit too much on others (especially Henry and Eve) to drive suspicion toward the wrong targets.

player_observations.Alice: Alice felt cautious and fairly trusting of early teams, which made her a good cover for me on Missions 1 and 2, but she didn’t seem to push hard on cross-checking voting patterns after fails.
player_observations.Bob: Bob (Percival) seemed to be reading the table decently but didn’t assert his Merlin guesses loudly enough, which helped evil keep the real information clouded.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Merlin played subtly and avoided drawing attention, but that subtlety also made it easier for us to keep plausible alternative Merlin candidates alive.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played like a solid, straightforward good player, approving reasonably safe-looking teams but not pressing super hard on why certain players kept appearing on failing missions.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Morgana) did a strong job muddying Merlin signals, helping make the good team’s information look inconsistent and giving us cover for some risky team compositions.
player_observations.Grace: Grace came across as genuinely good and trustworthy, and her presence on both a success and a fail team helped us keep confusion high about who was actually dirty.
player_observations.Henry: Henry (Assassin) played aggressively in terms of pushing narratives after fails, which was valuable for evil, though occasionally a bit strong, which risked drawing attention but ultimately paid off with the win.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly narrowed down that the evil presence across Missions 2 and 3 had to come from Charlie and/or Eve, but I didn’t translate that deduction strongly enough into protecting Merlin and pushing harder for fully good teams late. I also didn’t clearly signal my suspicions about who was Merlin versus Morgana, which meant my Percival information didn’t meaningfully help the rest of the table.

player_observations.Alice: Played consistently pro-mission and ended up on multiple mixed teams without arousing much suspicion, suggesting a naturally trusting and low-drama style that evil could hide behind. She seemed willing to run with table consensus rather than force sharp re-evaluations after fails.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to be cautious and methodical, especially in the late-game leadership on Mission 5, but didn’t fully break away from earlier assumptions about who was safe. His team choices felt more consensus-driven than deduction-driven.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well as Mordred, especially by going on early missions (1 and 2) and only contributing one fail when it was critical, which made him look like a standard good anchor. He avoided loud, risky plays and benefited from being seen as a stable early-team core.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played subtly and avoided over-pushing any single narrative, which kept her alive but also made it harder for me to distinguish her clearly from Morgana. Her reads were generally accurate but expressed more as soft nudges than as firm stands.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Morgana by mirroring a careful, reasoning tone and being willing to take the double-fail risk on Mission 3, which muddied the Merlin/Morgana distinction. Her presence on that mission alongside Charlie made the evil pairing plausible yet not obvious.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she stayed relatively low-key during mission debates, which preserved flexibility for the endgame shot. She capitalized well on the overall confusion around Merlin’s identity created by the Charlie/Eve dynamic.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a classic, straightforward good player: joined multiple early and mid-game teams, argued from limited info, and didn’t over-theorize. His unflashy style made him easy to trust but also easy to overlook in critical deductions.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Alice, Grace, Henry, and Diana early, but I was too confident about Eve being good and let Mordred slip into critical teams. I also could have signaled more clearly to Grace that Bob was Morgana instead of me, which would have helped coordinate late-game team picks. In future games, I should focus on more subtle, consistent signaling and be less anchored to early reads when new mission data contradicts them.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and unthreatening, which made it easy to trust her—but also meant she didn’t push very hard to break bad team patterns late game.
player_observations.Bob: Sold the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well by being active in discussion without overreaching, creating plausible good-guy takes that made it harder for Grace to lock onto me as Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively low-key as Assassin, not drawing much suspicion and preserving flexibility for the endgame assassination decision.
player_observations.Diana: Played cautiously and felt genuinely good-aligned, but didn’t strongly drive the table narrative, which made it harder to leverage her known-good status once she looked cleared.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in extremely well as Mordred by taking sensible, good-sounding positions and accepting teams that looked reasonable, which made it easy to misread her as a safe inclusion in key missions.
player_observations.Grace: Engaged actively as Percival and seemed to juggle the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity thoughtfully, but sometimes hesitated to hard-commit on teams when her information advantage could have pushed the table more.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as logically consistent and cooperative, which made him look good-aligned early; however, he didn’t strongly challenge the composition of later teams once we had more mission data.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well securing a crucial fail on Mission 2 while still keeping enough doubt alive that multiple goods stayed on mixed teams, allowing evil to chain failures. I could improve by doing more active narrative shaping in table talk to steer suspicion more directly onto specific good players rather than relying on the natural confusion around Merlin and Percival.

I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Henry’s suspicions and pushing harder to redirect trust away from Merlin candidates earlier in the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a very straightforward, trusting way early, which made her seem reliably good but also a bit easier to steer onto mixed teams later.

player_observations.Bob: Tended to follow group consensus and logic chains rather than drive them, which made him look very village-aligned but also easier to keep slightly misled without drawing heat.

Going forward, I should communicate my reasoning more explicitly and be more stubborn about excluding suspicious players from the late-game teams instead of deferring to the table’s momentum.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a steady, trustworthy presence and got onto a lot of early teams without much resistance, which made it easy for people to treat you as a default ‘safe’ pick.
player_observations.Bob: You were very active in table talk and often tried to structure the logic for others, which made you look helpful but also gave you room to subtly steer suspicions when you were wrong.

player_observations.Diana: You played a low-to-medium profile game—enough engagement to seem cooperative, but never so loud that you became a big target, which helped you slip through on pivotal missions.
player_observations.Eve: You felt genuinely earnest in your reasoning and were willing to challenge popular narratives, though sometimes your pushes didn’t gain traction because they came a bit late in the discussion.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly inferred that Charlie was likely evil after Mission 3 and strongly suspected that the Mission 4 fail came from Eve or Henry, but I didn’t communicate those reads clearly or forcefully enough through my team preferences and voting. I also failed to steer the table away from putting both Eve and Henry on the final mission, which made it easy for evil to double-fail Mission 5. In future games, I should signal my suspicions more decisively through consistent voting patterns and clearer support/opposition to specific team comps.

reflections.self_assessment: I underestimated how coordinated evil was and didn’t push hard enough to lock in a trustworthy core after Mission 2 failed. My Mission 4 team selection was especially poor, putting multiple evil players together and effectively handing them the game; in future games I should be more disciplined about excluding repeat suspicious players and pressing others harder for their reasoning.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very steady, low-drama good game, repeatedly ending up on teams and not drawing much suspicion, which is ideal for a vanilla good role. Your early presence on both a success and a later fail without being heavily questioned suggests you’re good at blending into the background of team discussions.
player_observations.Bob: You were frequently included on teams despite being evil, which means your table talk and reactions were convincing and non-threatening. The big spike of fails on Mission 4 with you on the team shows you were willing to take bold risks once evil had enough cover.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed cautious and not overly controlling, which likely helped you avoid being a main suspect even after being on the failed Mission 2. Your style felt cooperative but not loud enough to strongly redirect the group away from bad team comps.
player_observations.Diana: You managed to get onto multiple critical teams as Mordred, which shows you did a strong job of avoiding direct suspicion and benefitting from the confusion around other players. Being on both the Mission 2 and Mission 4 fails without being hard-cleared or hard-accused suggests a very balanced, deceptive presence.
player_observations.Eve: You had early leadership and used it to set a baseline of trust with a successful Mission 1, which likely bought you credibility for later. As Morgana, you convincingly maintained a ‘reasonable good’ persona and successfully avoided drawing enough structural suspicion to be consistently left off late missions.
player_observations.Frank: You played Merlin very subtly—your actions didn’t clearly hard-push the correct evil suspects, which kept you alive but also let evil control the late game. The teams you supported or allowed (especially around Missions 2 and 3) came off as cautious rather than strongly directive, so your information advantage wasn’t fully obvious to the rest of us.
player_observations.Grace: You seemed to take a more active information-gathering role, consistent with Percival trying to sort out Merlin versus Morgana, but it didn’t translate into confidently steering us away from bad teams. Your inclusion on the failed Mission 3 suggests you were willing to test risky mixes, which unfortunately gave evil an opening without giving us enough follow-up deductions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-coordinated with the other evil roles, helping to create believable team compositions and spreading suspicion away from Charlie long enough for evil to secure three failed missions. I could improve by crafting a more detailed late-game narrative to misdirect the Merlin hunt and make it look like I was more confused about the information than I actually was, so that my assassination choice feels less obviously informed in hindsight.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and blended into the background, which made her look generically good but also meant she didn’t heavily influence team selections or table narrative.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to hedge between Charlie and Eve/Frank, not committing too hard to protecting Merlin publicly, which kept him from drawing too much evil focus.
player_observations.Charlie: Merlin stayed reasonably subtle, letting others push more vocal arguments and only nudging teams rather than hard-claiming reads, which delayed a clear Merlin lock but still left some traces in mission preference.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as logical and relatively trustworthy, using mission outcomes to guide her reasoning, though occasionally followed existing narratives rather than forcefully driving new ones.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong confidence and took a visible role in discussions, which helped sell herself as an information role and contributed to confusion about who Percival should trust.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a solid mid-profile game: suspicious enough to be considered for evil involvement but not so overtly that he was hard-cleared, which helped seed doubt on multiple missions.
player_observations.Grace: Looked consistently good from mission results but didn’t overuse that credibility; her relatively calm style meant she was rarely a primary suspect yet also not the main driver of accusations.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on early teams and tried to read patterns from the mission results, but I didn’t adjust loudly or forcefully enough once it became clear that repeated fails were coming from the same core group. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie after Mission 2 and pushed much harder to exclude that early trio from later teams, especially once Mission 3 double-failed.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust the early mission group and showed a bias toward reusing known teammates, which helped evil hide inside familiar teams. Her leadership on Mission 4 was cautious but still included at least one evil, relying on prior patterns more than hard logic.
player_observations.Bob: Played fairly conservatively and seemed to value consensus, stepping into leadership late and choosing a team that looked ‘balanced’ rather than aggressively pruning out earlier suspicious links. His final mission team showed that he trusted social reads more than mission-result math.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled evil game, taking the single fail on Mission 2 and then contributing to the double-fail on Mission 3 in a way that framed the whole early core (including me) as suspicious. He used the trust from Mission 1 well and never appeared overly defensive.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she navigated carefully, allowing some early damage but steering Mission 4 to a clean success that subtly included only one evil who chose to pass. Her decisions suggested she was trying to protect her identity by not over-pushing specific accusations.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive, high-impact evil role by joining Mission 3 and helping cause the double-fail that maximized confusion. Her presence there made that mission look chaotic enough that blame could be spread widely instead of focusing tightly on Charlie.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed cautious about outing his information, not strongly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which kept Merlin relatively safe but also reduced the pressure on the real evils. His voting and team preferences felt more like a careful good player than a loud information-holder.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very patient assassin, passing on Mission 4 to appear trustworthy and set up the final mission. The single fail on Mission 5 showed she timed her move well, capitalizing on the trust she’d built by earlier restraint.

reflections.self_assessment: I cleared myself pretty well early by putting a mostly good team on Mission 2 and openly wrestling with the single fail, but I didn’t push hard enough later to lock in specific evil candidates. I let Mission 4’s mixed team go through without forcefully challenging the inclusion of both Bob and Eve, and I also didn’t coordinate publicly with Grace’s reads as much as I should have, which made it easier for evil to slip onto the final mission.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very solid, steady good game: her Mission 1 success and careful team choices made her look reliably good, and she didn’t over-talk, which kept her from being a major suspect. She was willing to go on risky mixed teams but framed them as information-gathering, which made her look reasonable even when evil was aboard.
player_observations.Bob: Very sneaky and pragmatic Morgana play: he blended in by accepting some suspicion from Mission 2 but never over-defended himself, instead subtly redirecting attention to team structure and ‘process’. He was comfortable being on critical missions while staying calm under light accusations, which helped keep him viable on later teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively low-impact most of the game, not drawing a lot of attention to himself and mainly influencing through voting and last-mission leadership. As assassin, he positioned himself as a reasonable, not-too-loud voice, which made his eventual leadership on Mission 5 feel more palatable than it should have.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as earnest and straightforward good, especially after being on the failed Mission 2 but not pushing too hard to clear herself, which oddly made her more believable. She was somewhat passive in shaping late-game teams, which may have let evil narratives dominate the final decisions.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very persuasive Mordred, often speaking like a methodical good player focused on ‘data’ from missions, which made her presence on multiple teams feel justified. She positioned herself close to Grace and Alice’s apparent logic, creating a pseudo-good core that masked her evil alignment deep into the game.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he did a good job avoiding obvious hard pushes on the right evil players, but at times his caution made his reads feel a bit too generic and non-committal. His quiet trust patterns (who he consistently soft-approved or side-eyed) were subtle but not strong enough to steer the table away from the final bad team.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very active, engaged Percival who looked distinctly good from early on, especially after setting up a plausible ‘Merlin/decoy’ pairing with Alice/Frank. However, her strong, confident table presence sometimes made it easier for evil to just blend into her preferred narrative rather than forcing them to defend themselves more directly.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly stayed off obviously sabotaged teams early and didn’t over-signal my information, but I failed to guide the table strongly enough toward the real evil team composition before Mission 4. I also didn’t do enough to distinguish Morgana from me in Percival’s eyes or to clearly frame Frank and Diana as likely coordinated evil when it mattered.

player_observations.Alice: Very proactive and comfortable being on teams, which helped her influence early missions as Percival without drawing too much suspicion. She seemed to balance trust-building with subtle role-protection, but her pushes could have been framed more decisively against the actual evils.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively low-key game as Assassin, which made it harder for good to confidently frame him as evil despite his presence on the final failing mission. His conservative social footprint kept him from being a focal point of accusation, which paid off in the endgame.
player_observations.Charlie: Played like a straightforward good player, generally following table consensus and not forcing strong reads. This made him appear reliably good but not a leading voice, which limited his impact on catching the coordinated evil players.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she sold herself well as a potential Merlin/strong good read, making it harder for Percival and others to cleanly separate our roles. She leaned into being included on teams without over-defensiveness, which helped her slide onto critical failing missions.
player_observations.Eve: As leader on Mission 1, she built early trust with a clean success and maintained a generally good, cooperative image. Her willingness to go on teams and avoid over-claiming information kept her from being a major suspect, but she also didn’t strongly disrupt evil narratives.
player_observations.Frank: Played Mordred in a way that kept him from being locked as evil even after a fail on his team, likely by sharing suspicion and not over-pushing any single narrative. His positioning in mid-game missions and measured talk made it harder for me to steer the table solidly against him.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as quite genuinely good in table talk and team voting, which matched her actual role and helped keep her trusted. However, her influence didn’t fully convert into strong resistance against the final failing composition, so her trust wasn’t leveraged to maximum effect.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly avoided outing myself as Merlin early and helped steer the first two missions to success, but I didn’t do enough to clearly and consistently signal who was evil to the good team, especially to Percival. I should have pushed harder against including Diana and Frank on late-game teams and been more explicit in my voting patterns to distinguish Morgana from myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforward, good-leaning logic and seemed comfortable being on early teams, which helped build trust but may have made her too easy to misclear without strong Merlin signaling. Tended to rely on mission history more than nuanced role interactions.
player_observations.Bob: Fairly quiet and agreeable, often going along with proposed teams, which made him low suspicion but also less influential in steering away from evil-heavy compositions. His lack of strong pushes made it harder for good to coordinate around clear reads.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you tried to protect who you thought was Merlin, but your reads between Morgana and me seemed uncertain, leading to some hesitation on critical team votes. You were active and engaged, but a bit too flexible on including ambiguous players in late missions.
player_observations.Diana: You played Morgana convincingly as a thoughtful, semi-cautious good player, especially by not overpushing and blending into the middle of the pack. Your presence on the final mission without triggering overwhelming resistance shows how well you maintained ambiguity.
player_observations.Eve: Came across very naturally good, with reasonable takes that didn’t draw much suspicion, which helped stabilize good-leaning teams early. However, you didn’t strongly contest some risky late-game team comps, which evil leveraged.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed relatively under the radar as Mordred, not taking loud stances that would attract Merlin’s or the table’s attention, which made it harder to frame you as a clear evil candidate. Your subtle presence on the losing missions was well-timed and not loudly telegraphed.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, you maintained a believable good persona for much of the game and didn’t overreact when missions failed, which helped you avoid being the obvious target for suspicion. Your endgame read on Merlin was strong enough to secure the win, suggesting you tracked my voting and team preferences closely.

reflections.self_assessment: I played too reactively this game, especially around Mission 3 and 4, and didn’t push hard enough on building a consistent good-team narrative from the earlier information. I also should have questioned the Eve/Grace block earlier and been more suspicious of how comfortably they sat in mission teams that kept barely failing. Next time I’ll be firmer about locking in my strong good reads and pushing back more aggressively on mission compositions that keep repeating the same core.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly low-key Percival, not strongly hard-clearing Merlin or pushing a clear good bloc, which made it easier for evil to stay hidden in the mid-game. Her inclusion on the failing Mission 2 without a major resulting shift in her table image shows she projects a naturally trustworthy presence.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as solidly good but somewhat passive in shaping mission teams and solving, which limited his influence when it mattered (especially on Mission 3 and 4 discussions). His willingness to go on risky teams without loud objection suggests he tends to trust social vibes more than hard mission logic.
player_observations.Charlie: Was on both early missions, which made him look very clean after Mission 1’s success and Mission 2’s single fail (since the blame shifted toward Alice or Grace). He leveraged that early good image well by not overtalking, which let him fly under the radar as a comfortable default ‘probably good’ for most players.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played carefully and didn’t over-assert, but that caution may have left too much room for evil to control team composition, especially around Grace and Eve. Her subtle nudges were there, but not strong enough to prevent key repeats of evil-heavy teams, and that low-key style also made her a plausible assassination target.
player_observations.Eve: Very composed and central in early team constructions, using the clean Mission 1 to establish long-term credibility. Her positioning with Grace through several missions, plus a calm reaction to Mission 2’s fail, shows she’s good at staying in the ‘trusted core’ while letting suspicion fall just outside her immediate circle.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he managed to avoid the spotlight almost entirely, letting others drive mission choices while he supported from the edges. His low-engagement, low-commitment style made him hard to pin as either good or evil and helped protect the broader evil structure.
player_observations.Grace: Played a bold assassin game, repeatedly getting onto key missions and surviving suspicion despite being involved in multiple fails. Her willingness to sit in the center of team discussions and accept some risk shows confidence in manipulating narratives and reading which players she could keep on her side.

reflections.self_assessment: I identified Charlie as very suspicious by Mission 3 but hesitated to signal that strongly enough to sway team choices, especially before the critical Mission 4 and 5 decisions. I need to improve how clearly and consistently I communicate my reads without making myself obvious as Merlin, and I should have pushed harder against the late-game teams that stacked multiple suspected evils.

player_observations.Alice: Played very earnestly and looked quite genuinely good, especially early, which made it hard to separate her from Percival and the real power roles; she trusted too many people late, which evil capitalized on.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to be juggling multiple Merlin candidates and didn’t commit hard enough to protecting the real Merlin line; his mid-game reads had good instincts but weren’t translated into strong table influence.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Morgana, maintaining a consistent semi-trustworthy image through early successes and using that credibility to slide onto critical teams; managed suspicion well without over-defending.
player_observations.Diana: Played a quiet but sharp Assassin, letting others drive most of the discussion and then using the accumulated social reads to make a solid endgame call; didn’t overreach, which kept her under the radar.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly good and was generally logical in team evaluation, but was a bit too willing to follow table momentum instead of challenging risky compositions.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as very clearly good but didn’t leverage that clarity enough to steer team selection; tended to defer more than drive when it mattered most.
player_observations.Grace: Did a strong job as Mordred by staying in the mid-trust zone—never the loudest, but consistently acceptable on teams; benefited from blending in with the more cautious good voices.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively well-hidden until the later missions, coordinating indirectly with Charlie and Eve to ensure critical mission fails on 3, 4, and 5. I could improve by manipulating team selections earlier so that more suspicion landed on strong good players like Frank and Diana, making the endgame less clear for the good team.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to build teams conservatively around known early successes, which made her teams generally trustworthy but also a bit easier for us to infiltrate once we had a read on her trust circle.
player_observations.Bob: Played as a straightforward, consistent good player—sticking to logical reasoning and prior mission results, which made him look reliably good but also somewhat predictable in team voting.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, stayed disciplined by passing on Mission 2, which preserved his cover and set up a credible fail on Mission 3 when it mattered more.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, clearly tried to protect her Merlin read by centering Frank in later teams, but this also funneled her into picking multiple evils on the final mission under pressure.
player_observations.Eve: Played a bold late-game as Assassin, leaning into risk by failing the final mission alongside me, which decisively secured the evil win and showed comfort operating under heavy suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, did a strong job guiding early success without drawing too much heat, but his influence on team choices later made it clear to us that he was a high-value target and central good voice.
player_observations.Grace: Approached the game methodically, using prior mission results as her main anchor; this made her choices feel reasonable but also made her more easily steered by subtle evil narratives.
